This is Chi'an Chi's doing, without a doubt. Too often have naive citizens of Cathay fallen under the Changer's wicked thrall. We must scour every home until we find the traitors who have ensorcelled these simple-minded simians.

We cannot hope to locate the agents of Chi'an Chi responsible for this simian menace, for the God of Lies excels  subterfuge. All we can do is slaughter every monkey on sight and pray nothing worse follows.
Their minds are out of balance. Only by the release of the excess Yin energies swirling within their skulls may harmony be regained. This will require the finest surgeons in all Cathay.

Let the afflicted rest and recuperate. The Winds forever shift, and so too will this magical malaise. Fine teas and medicinal herbs will leave them refreshed and more determined than ever to serve our Emperor.

Upon bathing in those sacred waters, not only will their fire be dimmed, but the Spirit Dragon will have their ancestors bear witness to their ugly fury. In their shame, they will know harmony once more.
localised_title: Send Them All to the Dragon River

localised_description: If the fury cannot be quenched, perhaps it can be mastered. Breathing exercises will calm them until the next battle, and there they can unleash this rage upon deserving targets.
Though his manner is abhorrent, we have much to learn from this well-travelled thug. His permanent services will be costly to secure, but every one of our warriors will greatly benefit.
Let the Maneater feast upon the finest meats and richest wines Grand Cathay has to offer. Soon enough, secrets will spill from his drunken, drooling maw.

Absurd though it seems, you sense in this creature a maternal care toward you. Upon its back, barely visible, blue furs create the shape of a crescent moon. You should show her that you adore her too.

As you fight the strange urge to bow, the cat's tail twitches impatiently. Along its length is red patterning which uncannily resembles a great serpent. The haughty feline refuses table scraps, but perhaps an offering of sublimely roasted boar leg would suffice?
Perhaps they are evil spirits – Chi'an Chi takes many forms. There’s a well nearby – grab the cats by the scruff and cast them in!
Breathe deep of the strange vapours within, and you shall be infused with the Winds themselves. As the harmonious power of Yin pulses through your veins, none will even dream of questioning you.
All the Emperor's subjects should prosper from this singular discovery. Should we sink the opened chest into the river, the swirling magic within will touch every soul in the land.
localised_title: Add It to the Water Supply

localised_description: Beware of strangers and their exotic gifts. Kill this imposter and have this box buried with them!

The apparition of their disapproving forebears, beseeching them to pursue peace, will surely soften their hearts towards us. They will never know that this was merely an illusion wrought by our most inventive Alchemists.
Let us spread the rumour that our foe has fallen under the sway of the Great Enemy. Incensed by this supreme act of blasphemy and corruption, our legions will fight more tirelessly than ever before.
Execute one fifth of the army. They are short-lived mortals, and some will be traitors. The rest will be scared to act further.
Lace the bananas and melons with serpent venom, and this infestation shall soon run its course. Disposing of the endless simian corpses will be a fiendish task, however.
Medicine and supplies will restore our beleaguered forces.
The Blood God’s minions have nothing on me.
One of your Sorcerers believes they can translate one of the inscriptions. Runic magic is generally beneath notice, but perhaps something of minor worth may result from this endeavour.

Zuvassin's mouthpiece claims that emptying a sack of gold into the nearest river will cause an equal number of eyeballs to rain from the sky – consuming them will grant your legion sight beyond sight.
Order the construction of a great war-pit, where you will challenge your doubters to face you in unarmed combat. Few will dare attempt this.
Order all involved in the libidinous rite flayed to death, and a vast and bleeding statue of your own form constructed from their remains.
Rather than end the carnal ceremony, you could take your measure of pleasure. The experience will be unforgettable, though your followers will regard you with disdain.
If the eight-pronged star of Chaos is burned into the screaming fiend's hide, they will know rage as never before.
The near-forgotten symbol of the first Everchosen is reputed to grant unnatural power to those whose flesh bears it.
The colossal goblet, carved from a great skull of unknown origin, houses a gallon of boiling blood. Drinking deep of it will demonstrate your incomparable courage.
The yellow growth palpitates horribly. The thought of forcing the pulsing, reeking malignancy down your throat is nauseating, but it would earn the Fly Lord's love.
The crystal vial houses a lilac fluid, its scent intoxicating. You sense that dousing yourself with it will cause indescribable agony – but render you irresistible.
The nine-eyed, twisted face upon the hovering book's leathery cover tries to tear itself free at your approach. It seeks to bond itself to your flesh.
Order the immediate execution of every mortal kept in your dungeons and torture chambers, then burn the bodies in a vast pyre. The touch of Chaos shall grow yet stronger.
Desperate measures are called for. Only by tearing the ears from the skulls of every single fiend in your populace may they become immune to Slaanesh's hypnotic beat.
There is nothing for it but to join the dread drumming yourself. Perhaps it will inspire you to greater feats of slaughter? Or perhaps it will enable Slaanesh to seduce more to his cause?
At significant cost and effort, capture a pack of starving Yhetees from the mountains, and allow your followers to slake their battle-thirst upon the raging ice-beasts.
Summon an ambassador from every empire – an unprecedented conclave of all this world's powers. Then disembowel them where they stand, and claim their high-ranking skulls for Kharneth.
Raze everything in your kingdom that is not brass, bone or steel. Leave nothing living, save for the mightiest of your Daemons.
If your blood legion is rendered irreversibly immune to Slaaneshi charms, they will surely prevail in battle against the Perfect Prince's perfumed fiends.
Storm every home, and behead any being caught in an act of congress. To be on the safe side, the same applies to all those guilty of reading poetry, playing games of chance, or drinking fine wines.
A simple proclamation of approval from the Skull Throne would be sufficient to send countless Daemons flocking to your cause.
No trinket can make an act of mercy forgivable. Ignore the relic, and grant a brutal second death to each and every one of these Unliving wretches.
Arrange for the capture of one of their weaker underlings. They will yield soon their secrets if they value their skull.

Instil new fervour within the populace. Make every child understand exactly what happens when Ruin visits Kislev. As the nightmares grip them, they will beg their parents to protect them, no matter the cost.
The other kingdoms do not realise how close doom is to their doors. We must send our most gifted orators to make these pampered fools understand. Once they do, they will surely aid our cause.
Have the farmer ask this crack of his to grant Kislev's armies the strength of the soil.
Have the farmer request that the Motherland bless us with the power of the elements.
Years of flash-flooding and countless thousands of footsteps have taken a heavy toll on the ancient market. Restore its former glory, and goods will flow like never before.
We have long consigned Bretonnian artisans to one of the most forlorn areas of the city, but they do know a thing or two about steel. Let us gain their favour, and in turn their wisdom.
Food is too precious in Praag to waste even this monstrously spoiled harvest. Perhaps it may even be a boon to sorcery, though who knows what horror will we invite across our threshold?
Though our populace will go hungry, we cannot permit this foul affliction to pass into proud Kislevite blood. Once the fasting is done, purity shall reign.

If trust is so hard won, then, alas, fear it must be. Have our most devout Patriarchs flay his traitorous flesh, remove his fingers then, finally, burn him alive. There will doubtless be turmoil, but we can control that.

The free-thinking heretic is, alas, undeterred. He now tells the subjects that we attempted to threaten him into silence. Preposterous! And does he not realise that it is only through faith that the dread taint of Chaos is kept at bay?
Smear the buboe with carrion, mulch and excrement in the hope it will grow yet more fecund, and thus feed the land with Nurgle's putrescent power.
Whatever pestilent horrors swim within this vast and necrotic edifice shall be loosed upon the land, spreading the Urfather's foul touch wherever they go.
The vast cadaver will make a fine breeding ground for pox-spreading insects. The foul grubs will grow fat upon its mouldering flesh, and upon reaching adulthood they will blight the land.
If your rotted legion barely have minds left to twist, they will become inherently resistant to madness. Tzeentch's changelings will thus be powerless against them.
All corvids must be slain on sight. In fact, anything with feathers is fair game, lest it be a sorcerous emissary of the Raven God.
The filthy flood-waters contain generations of waste, and thus will be a breeding ground for manifold new and wondrous diseases. Truly, this is a miracle of science!
Order your Tallybands to bathe in the disease-strewn brown waters. The countless bacteria within shall work wonders upon their festering flesh.
Miracles should not be expected, for Plaguebearers' vocal cords have nigh-on rotted away. Guiding them into a simple three-note refrain will yield potent results, however.
While this has perhaps unwelcome overtones of Slaaneshi sorcery, causing a high-ranking foe to become captivated by your singularly horrendous form would yield invaluable insights.
Maybe they're bored of eatin' the same ol' raw flesh for sixteen meals a day. Tell the Butchers to make somethin' fancier, like stuffin' one kind of meat with another kind of meat. Delicious, yeah?

Get raidin' like never before, and round up the finest meats, cheeses, cakes and boozes in the 'old world. We're gonna have ourselves the buffet to end all buffets. If this don't fatten 'em up, nothin' will.
This ain't natural. Probably them Chaos lads are muckin' about again. Whatever it is, we ain't got no use for skinny Bulls. Might as well feed 'em to somethin' wot will eat, yeah?
Feed 'em them lava-chillies the Butchers have been too scared to touch. Once they've finished thrashing in agony they'll soon be belchin' fire. Maw only knows what they'll break first, mind.
All that grease on their flesh will make our boys burn a treat. They won't thank us for the pain and the flames'll probably spread, but the scars'll make 'em tough as old boots.
Tasty as this magic meat tree looks, if we gnosh the whole thing now it ain't never gonna grow more chops. Just pick the ripe ones, yeah?
It'll fill up the loot-pile alright, but the tribe ain't gonna be 'appy that you ain't sharin' it around. They'll probably 'ave a massive sulk.
A few shiny things for every Bull sounds a like a plan. They'll surely blow it all on meat 'n' booze, and maybe stop botherin' you for it for a while.
It don't matter 'ow that beast ended up so weird, we can't let good meat go to waste. Get those 'earts cooked sharpish, then get 'em in the tribe's guts.
localised_title: Put the Hearts in the Pot

localised_description: We can thump some sense into 'em. Or out of 'em, as the case may be. The other Gnoblars'll look at 'em funny, but that don't matter.
Fair's fair, the tribe's only had eight breakfastses today. Stuff a bit more fat 'n' grease down 'em and they'll be right as rain. Better, even.
We'll lose a few boys in the process, but we can make these pups do what we says. Once they're all grown up, we got ourselves a weapon, yeah?
There'll be Bulls queuing up to fight for ya if it means they get to splatter some of this red stuff on their lunch. 'Course, they'll probably eat us outta house and home.
No self-respectin' Ogre stuffs anything that ain't meat down their maw. Get the tribes back on a pure-flesh diet, and their guts'll soon be bigger than ever.
Your pleasure-toys will rhapsodise about the drink's wondrous qualities to their countless other partners. Soon enough, all will beg to join your cause, hoping for a taste of their own.
Somehow, lust has been swapped for rage. To undo this will require a great harvest of souls, which will then be imbibed by your populace. Their loins shall soon be aflame once more.
There is Khornate blood in the water supply: so that is how this pleasure-slaying sabotage was wrought. There is nothing for it but wait for the boiling ichor to drain away.
Absence makes the heart grow fonder – and no doubt the loins too. If the people are forcibly denied that which they have grown bored of, they will soon desperately desire its return.
So nightmarish and so endless is the composition that eardrums will burst, eyeballs will melt and brains will bleed. This mass sacrifice will be delicious indeed, and the dark rewards immeasurable.
localised_title: Host a Public Reading, in Full

localised_description: Send the Druchii to your decadent brothers and sisters in sin. They will be so very easily made willing, and your freshly-satiated kin will owe you a debt of gratitude.

If it is cruelty they desire, then cruelty they shall receive. Release the Druchii, naked and unarmed, into battle, and no servant of Kharneth will be able to resist this invitation to slaughter. The distraction will serve us well.

One unforgettable night of fine wine, heavenly music and extreme debauchery will be all it takes to coax secrets and strategies from their hungry lips. How Slaanesh will revel in our foe's subsequent suffering.
Scour the libraries for spells of voiding. If one does not work, move on to the next. Do whatever it takes to find a magical vaccine for Nurgle's latest pox.

When sufficient numbers of the Changer's Followers have dissolved into horrific goo, those not yet infected will most probably be immune to the plague's deliquescent touch. The casualties shall be many, however.
Have your Sorcerers invoke a great ward of stabilisation. Though draining, it should lock your followers' fluctuating forms to this plane of existence.
Chant the scar-drawn runes aloud, and your changelings' limbs will catch alight with blue-gold fire – all the better to burn away diseased flesh.
The inscription will grant voice to your army's every missile, magical or otherwise – an ethereal shriek capable of reversing decay.
Their flesh shall erupt in squirming tendrils and shapeless new limbs, chattering mouths will sprout upon their hides, and indescribable new creatures shall be birthed from their spines.
All reason shall leave them, and they shall forever speak in half-truths, impossible prophecies and unknown tongues. All who hear them will suffer the same fate.
Once the disembodied digits dig painlessly into the eyeballs of your foe's soldiers, their sight shall become yours. The cost of concealing this grand act of sorcery will, however, be high.

An unnatural aggression takes hold of the populace; a seething frustration that explodes at the slightest provocation. Even the most placid soul becomes as quick to anger as a rabid dog. Soon enough, the fighting begins. The streets are littered with the dazed and beaten, and the gutters run red with blood.

Exploring too deep into an ancient cave system, a forager unwittingly brings back with them a hitherto unknown and devastating disease – one which now spreads like wildfire throughout the populace. Beware the coughing! Spurn the sneezing! Run screaming from the feverish!

A travelling clothier sets up her stall, offering garments tailored so masterfully that they are like a second skin. All who don her garments become consumed by self-obsession, forever admiring their own reflections and refusing all other duties. Undeterred, countless more queue out the door.

Chen – single word, shredding sanity wherever it is spoken. They say a large, black bird was the first to utter it, and now all who hear it soon say nothing else, laughing hysterically as they bark into the ears of those around them. "Chen! Chen! Chen! CHEN!"

The people report sightings of flickering figures in their homes, chanting in oddly familiar voices. One is even certain she saw the faces of her long-dead grandparents. Before these reports can be corroborated, the ancestor spirits – if that is what they are – disappear. In their wake, the land knows harmony.

There is a shudder from the Celestial Palace, and the sound of straining metal, as the Wu Xing Compass works its sorcery. Each warrior suddenly finds within their pocket a chipped stone from the Great Bastion itself – a ward against the Great Enemy, a token of the Emperor’s love.

Foolishly seeking to unlock the sorcerous potential of a Maw Shard, a rogue Alchemist meets a messy end. However, his failed experiment casts a potent illusion upon all Ogre-kind – to Cathayan eyes, the brutes now appear to have the faces of cats. Where once there was fear, there is now amusement.

Disaster strikes, as a sudden storm blows a colossal Sky-Junk into a mountainside. The impact shakes loose a legion of long-lost Terracotta Sentinels, stationed immobile since some ancient campaign. Fortunately, many can be restored, while those demolished in the fall can be used to repair others of their kind.

Determined to please Khorne further, his servants elect to brand their own hides with His flaming icon. Their screams are beyond horrifying, and the caustic stench of burning Daemon flesh is unforgettable, but the rite plunges them into an enduring hunger for slaughter, requiring no other sustenance.

Nurgle's Rot is a slow death sentence for mortals, but amongst the Urfather's faithful it is a source of strength. The Fly Lord's putrescent devotees are thus delighted by their discovery of a new strain of this divine contagion, one that numbs their senses as it ravages their flesh.

Somewhere far beyond, Slaanesh knows the ecstasy of satisfaction. Afterwards, as the Perfect Prince slumbers in His forbidden boudoir, the howling sweetness of His dreams touches each and every one of His servants. Sated, they need nothing else for now.

A strange calm comes over those who pledge themselves to the Raven. They refuse all food and rest, and work tirelessly. When pressed on the matter, they all chant the same chant: "We want for nothing today, for great Tzeentch has shown us the rewards we will know tomorrow."

The land itself erupts in obsidian spines from far below, some coated in crimson blood, some in noxious bile, others exuding a bewitching, bittersweet fragrance, and others still bearing a shimmering halo of eldritch flame. The Ruinous Powers lay claim to this realm...

A Norscan Shaman reports a vision of a far-off kingdom razed to ash, its every inhabitant slaughtered, of nothing left but a mountain of skulls. Though none know where this land is, the joyous news of Khorne's distant triumph means countless Daemons jockey for the opportunity to achieve similar here.

No realm can be truly considered cleansed of life by merely scourging its surface. In sewers and caverns the Skaven lurk, always. Eight thousand barrels of boiling blood solve the problem neatly. As countless vermin are roasted alive in their foul nests, the land itself becomes a monument to Khorne.

As one, unbidden, dozens of Daemons begin to chant. "Blood for the Blood God! Skulls for the Skull Throne! BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD! SKULLS FOR THE SKULL THRONE!" They continue this tirelessly for days, then suddenly all drop dead. There is a laugh like thunder, and the skies blacken.

Tired of waiting for the next battle, a troop of Bloodletters storm out of camp. They maraud across the land, slaughtering without discretion, their rage growing with each kill. Ultimately, they turn upon each other. Though none survive, word of their brutal deeds inspires others to similar feats of carnage.

You stumble upon an Ogre camp. A Butcher escapes the slaughter by promising untold power. He slices and stews the entrails of his fallen kin, creating a foaming red broth which causes hide to harden and muscle to swell. Though useful, all sorcery offends Khorne, and so the Butcher is slain.

Madame Valentina, a singularly fearsome Ice Witch, retired years ago. But she has spent the time since tutting at falling standards, at Ice Maidens who barely know Frost Blade from Crystal Cloak, and she can stand no more. When she raps furiously upon the Ice Court’s doors, none dare refuse her.

Your Lancers bring you the bones of a long-lost Tzar, discovered while patrolling the oblast. Into a reliquary box they go, holy relics of an ancient war to defend Kislev’s vast borders. Inspired by this proof that their rulers too sacrifice everything for the Motherland, your legions take heart.

Officially, the Ice Court only accepts young women of noble lineage, for only they deserve its timeless wisdom. Exceptions are sometimes made, though none may talk of it. When a farmer beseeches the Court, offering a thousand saddlebags of blood-stained gold, his daughter is accepted without question.

Many believe that the Motherland is alive, and loves her people as they love her. When disease claims the lives of every man, woman and child in five stanitsas, the icy wind takes on a new timbre, one that sounds like a sorrowful howl. The land will surely make amends.

The Patriarchs descend upon every home, rooting through drawers and overturning bookshelves in search of any hint of heresy. Countless Kislevites are dragged from their beds and executed. Who can say how many were innocent? Nevertheless, purity – or, at least, terrified obedience – is restored.

Feeding War Bears is an expensive business – the beasts consume their own body weight in meat daily. The discovery of an enormous Slaaneshi cult hiding in Erenegrad's sewers is thus an occasion for celebration rather than dismay. Blasphemy is duly purged, and the bears sleep well.

Many equate Nurgle with death, but this is to misunderstand His intent. He desires rebirth, so that more death may follow. So it is that He raises the bones of the long-dead, and from them sprouts bilious flesh. Nurgle's newest children strike up their buzzing drone, and the cycle begins anew.

Morrslieb grows full, casting its sickly green light across the land. The Fly Lord’s children rejoice, for contagion thrives under the Chaos moon’s cold shadow. The rotted legion erupts in fresh sores and, in horrifying unison, coughs a constant cough, spraying fountains of plague-ridden spittle with every phlegmy bark.

The droning of Nurgle's Plaguebearers is feared across the land, for all know it heralds lingering, fever-wracked death. However, an unusually enterprising Tallyband drift from their usual monotone and chant their chilling dirge in a hitherto-unheard frequency – one which immediately loosens the bowels of all for miles around.

An uncommonly bloated Plague Toad is drawn helplessly to the befoulment of a nearby sewer, but cannot squeeze itself through the entry grate. With a final terrible lunge, it wrenches itself across - tearing its vast belly open in the process. The countless black maggots within surge into the local water supply.

The earth of every town, every village, every field and every forest simultaneously sprouts a single Nurgling. The tiny Daemons stand stock-still, their rictus grins never changing. On the seventh day of this, all suddenly burst, releasing an immense cloud of flies that quickly disperse, turning the very skies yellow.

Your plague-scientists have been busy. From their squalid laboratories they birth a brand new contagion, one they proudly dub 'Raven Rot'. Remorselessly, the pox ravages eldritch feathers and chews at ectoplasmic flesh. Truly, it is a beautiful disease, one that silences the arrogant bluster of the Changer’s iridescent slaves.

Your pock-marked children pick idly at their own scabs as they await the next battle. After a time, they fall into a strange and silent trance, and continue picking until their entire hides hang off them in grisly ribbons. As their ruined flesh knits, it hardens into thick, body-wide callouses.

A storm darkens the skies, but there is no lightning – instead, there comes a hail of man-sized, pus-filled seeds. As they implant themselves in the earth, it becomes iron-hard and sprouts vast and pungent fungal foundations. Praise be to Nurgle, for He shares His garden's bounty!

Those farmsteads unfortunate enough to be proximate to your tribes have long accepted that the price of their survival is eye-wateringly high. The great day has rolled around once again, and when your followers eventually stir from their grease-stained beds, they are presented with veritable mountains of slaughtered lambs and calves.

Your henchmen drag an unusually lucid Gorger before you. Unlike its solitude-maddened kin, the elephantine, sinewy horror will obey basic commands. This proves particularly useful during contract negotiations. A mere snap of the fingers will see the other party’s head torn from their shoulders – a superior rate is thus guaranteed.

One of your Butchers laces his latest dish with oddly-glowing mushrooms from the deepest caves. The tribe who consumes it soon enters a state of euphoria. As one, they begin to dance, their thunderous footsteps toppling trees and shaking boulders from mountains. Even the very shadows retreat from the cacophony.

An enterprising Slaughtermaster hits upon the idea of fashioning crude, oversized slip-on noses and ears from leftover scraps of hide. Desirous of these absurd prosthetics, countless Gnoblars flock to your cause – for in their abhorrent society there is no greater sign of station than a bulbous snout and mammoth lugs.

A wandering Hunter shares his tall tales with the tribe. In one, he claims to have trapped and eaten a dragon, and that the taste was beyond compare - like the most succulent chicken marinated in the finest spices. The tribe is instantly decided: they must experience this singular flavour themselves.

Though Gnoblars are highly irritating creatures, the larger ones have occasional moments of brilliance. One of your favourites takes it upon itself to spread a rumour that consuming the gizzard of a Daemon will make one's gut double in size. To say the tribe is motivated would be an understatement.

Mutation is usually the bailiwick of Tzeentch, but it has its uses for Slaanesh. There is a moan from beyond, and your followers sprout gossamer, lavender tendrils. Wherever they tread, their new fronds help themselves to flesh, caressing and lashing, clasping and tantalising, bringing shivers of ecstasy to all around.

In dreams, the Perfect Prince touches every mind, granting fevered visions of their darkest desires. The strongest are buoyed by these indescribable peaks of sensation, awakening fulfilled like never before, but the weakest cannot endure. Their spent, desiccated forms crumble, and the very land feeds upon their tormented souls.

A euphoric compulsion takes hold of every soul in the land, and they each proudly send you a missive containing their darkest, guiltiest secret. When reason returns to them, they swear unwavering subservience – in exchange for a promise that their shameful truths shall never be revealed.

Your Fiends learn to howl in a hypnotic harmony that implants an overwhelming suggestion into the minds of all around. Across the land, hands claw feverishly at belt buckles and blouse buttons, walls shake and beds break. Calls for order fall upon deaf ears, for all are lost in bliss.

In a moment of indulgence, you grant one of your followers the honour of becoming tonight's concubine. Basking in the afterglow of pleasure and suffering beyond all mortal imagining, they henceforth carry themselves with unshakeable confidence, convinced of their own greatness.

Your perfumiers have designed a new scent to confound the senses, one which causes all those who inhale it to helplessly bellow their deepest desires aloud. By dousing themselves in this delicious fragrance, your Daemonettes are granted all the insight they need to bewitch their weak-minded foes.

As one, your followers begin to skip in and out of existence. One second they are there, one second they are not, then they reappear, and so forth. With each reappearance, they sport fresh new feathers, resplendent in blue and gold, and speak in a different tongue.

A swarm of shimmering blue-pink sigils appears suddenly upon every available surface, each one contradicting the last. Some who gaze upon them strike up uncontrolled screaming, while others chant in a tongue unrecognisable to even Tzeentch's most trusted servants. It is then that the sigils begin to whisper.

An eerie freneticism falls upon your scribes as they study their tomes, refusing rest and sustenance. As they read, their craniums swell and swell, until their engorged brains spill from their skulls – yet still they read. On the ninth morning, their vast minds consume the rest of their malnourished forms.

Wealth is a dull necessity in the mortal realm, but there are ways to make its acquisition more entertaining. Deep in His Impossible Fortress, the Changer inscribes a flaming rune into the very air. Far away, a single ear of each of your followers is transmuted into solid gold.

Those of your followers lucid enough to care report strange behaviour from their own shadows. The shades appear to move of their own accord, never quite mirroring the actions of their casters. Soon enough they tear themselves free and stand upright – unnerving yet loyal two-dimensional replicas of those who bore them.

Without warning, nine city-sized blue and yellow runes manifest in the skies. The moment they disappear, the same rune carves itself into the left cheek of all who witnessed it. Their eyes turn immediately white, their mouths seal over and they stand stock-still, awaiting instruction.

You welcome the visit from Ulthuan.
These warriors are mighty and terrifying, yet each one that leaves the forest to fight weakens it, if only temporarily.
The Dryads have been sent to the Wildwood.
The Dryads have been put to the torch.
Your Wardancers leap to the opportunity.
The Asrai thirst for battle.
A shrine to the wise and just ruler of the Elven Pantheon.
A shrine to the harsh and ruthless God of Battle.
The Wood Elves of the Moonspring Glades have struck upon a trove of information.
The greatest shock for the Asrai was the discovery that they were not alone in the forest...
This one has walked through the fires of insanity, and found an ethereal strength on the other side...
Your warriors fight on following the funeral.
The forest has reclaimed its child.
The weapons created here not only provide a literal edge in battle, but improve the leadership of those wielding them.
Athel Loren celebrates the Hunt.
The soul of the forest is sacred.
The shadowed Night Glens are awash with forbidden and arcane magics.
The boughs spread, the vines grow, and life explodes from the Deepwood once more…
As the forest regenerates, so too do the Wood Elves…
Things may move a little slower until Athel Loren is... curtailed.
Continue the feast, for now.
The time has come to sacrifice our guests.
Athel Loren demands vengeance, and would have you exact it.
Once again, your Branchwraiths rule the forest!
More than ever, your Waystalkers are attuned with their forest homeland.
Your Spellsingers have joined their minds to the forest's sleeping consciousness and are at their best!

Karak Eight Peaks has been lost yet again to forces foul! Clan Angrund is once more dishonoured, and will be until this ancient Hold is recaptured. Until then, all Dwarfs across the Karaz Ankor will hold King Belegar personally responsible!
Recapturing Karak Eight Peaks will be no easy task, that much is certain. Another certainty is that all those joining this undertaking will require great compensation.

Karak Eight Peaks is safe in Dawi hands once more and King Belegar sits once more upon its throne. Even though much of the Hold is in a state of disrepair, Clan Angrund have at least begun to regain their former glory.
Belegar and his loyal followers have struck an Ancestral grudge from the great book and restored Clan Angrund to its former glory.
Uses the Underway to traverse the world.

Before the loss of the Eight Peaks, Belegar’s Ancestors were the kings of the nigh-impregnable fortress for many generations. The Angrund Clan is steeped in centuries of military understanding and has a keen eye for the particulars of siege warfare.

Skarsnik is a meddlesome and cunning Night Goblin, preferring to taunt and torment his opponents rather than swiftly killing them. Ever the sneakiest of his kind, he leads his forces on feints and duplicitous manoeuvres that leave his enemies bewildered, beleaguered, and - eventually - destroyed.

Wurrzag’s power and influence are beyond question. Those that know his abilities obey; those who do not, suffer. His retinue of Savage Orcs has vowed to stand by ‘Da Great Green Prophet’ to the end, and their strength has inspired countless other Greenskins to war in their turn.
This army has Rangers from a nearby region scouting the surrounding terrain for them.
Karak Eight Peaks has been taken by those annoyingly persistent stunty gits. If the name of Skarsnik is ever to strike fear into his enemies’ meagre hearts again then it must be recaptured. Now!
Karak Eight Peaks is once again the prized possession of Skarsnik, ‘Warlord of the Eight Peaks’! Now, all effort must be expended to ensure it remains that way.
The Lady's blessing is a wondrous gift freely graced upon all Bretonnian subjects, should they but kneel and utter their devotion.
Your actions are courageous and show goodness of intent.
Your actions bring prosperity to Bretonnia; the outside world looks on enviously.
Your actions inspire your warriors and strike fear into your enemy’s craven hearts.
Your actions are saintly – the kingdom was built on such noble foundations.
Your actions honour Bretonnia, its people, and their way of life. For the Lady!!!

It is unacceptable to declare war on another Bretonnian faction! Think of the code!
The insidious, sickening Greenskins are coming!
Devoted to the God of the Sea, Alberic and his elite, seafaring Knights rule the coastline with absolute authority.
A figure of awe and influence, the Fay Enchantress is the Lady’s personal representative and, some say, the true power in Bretonnia.
The greatest Bretonnian leader since Gilles the Uniter, King Louen is a mighty warrior-king – the very pinnacle of Knightly perfection.
Purging the land of evil is a great thing, both for Bretonnia and indeed the wider world.
Although they are our enemies, we belong to the same race. To destroy their settlements would be villainy indeed!
No virtuous Knight searches for gold while there is evil to root out in the Lady's blessed name!
No Lord who spills blood for financial gain can be considered honourable.
No Lord who spills blood for financial gain can be considered honourable.
The merchants enjoy a taste of the food otherwise destined for noble tables.
The peasants fight for any scraps they can take and seem satisfied, not that anyone cares...
Our nobles take what they want, but naturally this has slowed production somewhat.
Our armies march well on full bellies, but the peasants may starve as a result. Oh well...
The army may be happy, but the land is not. Restraint is key to balance in nature.
We cannot risk another outbreak, for the pox is virulent and crippling to the population.
Such quality, such opulence is sure to improve Bretonnia's reputation.
Dear Lady, we thank thee for the fruits of the land...
A repeat performance is very definitely in order!
Our cities blossom due to the efforts of artisans from abroad.
Our artisans seem grateful... not that anyone cares if they're not!
Pride always comes before a fall. These fits of ego are becoming rather expensive!
They are complaining too much. Perhaps examples should be made?
A wondrous sight indeed, dedicated to the blessed Lady of the Lake.
The peasants heed the warning. Just as well, for the alternative is death.
Bretonnian law is just and true, as are its noble judges.
A stern warning should be sufficient to deter such behaviour.
The Lady will ensure that our gifted children are schooled correctly in the use of magic.
The children will be trained in the ways of battle; they will be the finest soldiers in Bretonnia.
Such a beautiful statue is truly inspirational to behold.
The statue provides protection from evil, as if the Lady herself was standing watch over her flock.
These hunting grounds have improved the nobles' equestrian skills and made them happy.
The nobles know these places well, so the hunt is over quickly - and with a favourable conclusion.
The Lady has granted us knowledge that will help us in the future.
Rejoice! We have been granted the Blessing of the Lady.
On this occasion, a letter; next time, the lance.
Their meaningless words are but idle chatter, and should be ignored.
We cannot risk another smallpox outbreak - the peasant population is getting too low!
Smallpox has devastated some of our villages. Who will plough the fields?
Beautiful churches and breathtaking tournament grounds can now be built.
The epidemic may reoccur and the enemy may attack at any time. Be watchful.
The peculiar hue covering our lands spreads fear and disorder among the dull and stupid peasants.
The most beautiful buildings in the land! The flower of Bretonnian architecture.
All battles fought by Bretonnians are glorious by their very nature.
A lot of food was lost during the witch-hunt. Oh well, it is only the peasants that will starve...
The army is exhausted, almost as if their energy was drained by magical means...

The Winds of Magic shift and grow, becoming powerful enough to be observed. Howling just beyond hearing, they cannot be heard, but can be perceived. The Chalice of Potions glows with a brighter aura, and all those who see it know its power. The Fay Enchantress wonders if this will be enough...

The Troll King is possessed of a grim and malevolent cunning, seeking always to grind the realms of man under his monstrous rule.
The ability to irrefusably challenge anyone - or anything - in their native language ensures that Wulfrik's Ruinous quest will never end.
Without steel against their skin the men fall too easily.
It is hard to cut through enemy armour without a weapon to hand.
The Wolves strike with such force it tears apart your foes!
The speed of the horses ensures no enemy escapes with their life.
The Gods have blessed your blades, although your smiths did not have metal to spare for armour.
Your armour has the favour of the Gods - a shame there was not sufficient metal for your blades too.
You take their farms and steal their food to fuel your warriors.
You bring down their walls and level their buildings, carrying off everything of value.
You rush into battle eager to spill blood for your Gods!
Take what you want to make yourself stronger!
Only the strong are fit to survive and thrive!
Bathe in the blood of your enemies!
True champions survive all tests.
Strengthened, you press on to ever greater conquests!
You need meat to keep your warriors strong!
Any man who complains of being tired will be left behind.
Even in the lands of the eternal sun your warriors are supreme.
The Gods smile on you as you bring death and destruction!
When you endure the savagery of the north, nothing else compares.
A blade is the only tool needed to destroy the enemy.
Your armies move with care, though much slower than usual.
Your armies march on regardless, but there are some losses on the road.
The creatures that serve you are made stronger by the Gods!
The Gods honour your warriors with incredible might!
Our armies grow in size and ability!
Our tribe expands, taking more land!
Your men struggle to make headway in the harsh ice.
With no arm guards, your men get maimed more often.
Your Werekin gain the favour of the Gods.
Your Fimirs gain the favour of the Gods.
Such riches lost! But the Gods are content.
You keep your plunder, but the Gods are not happy at the loss of their shrines.
More blades and armour lets you press deeper into the southlands!
The food and drink sustains your warriors, giving them new strength to conquer enemy lands!
Make your buildings stronger with the knowledge of the forefathers!
Give your enemies a taste of the blades of the Ancestors.
Over many battles and countless acts of treachery, Chieftain Tretch Craventail of Clan Rictus has proven himself a master of guile.

The Longbeards are even more visibly (and audibly) annoyed, their murmurs of displeasure echoing throughout the Holds and Underways.
The Longbeards are silent because there are very few grudges unaccounted for, much to their annoyance as they like a good moan.

The concentration of your forces in this region is inflaming the rivalries within the horde.
Archaon the Everchosen is the Lord of the End Times, the vessel through which the Dark Gods unite their followers and turn the whole world into a Realm of Chaos.
Kholek is a Shaggoth of tremendous age. He is one of the first-born kin of Krakanrok the Black, father of the Dragon Ogres. Where the Herald of the Tempest walks, a raging storm blots out the sun.

Though he appears to be little more than sixteen summers of age, Sigvald the Magnificent has blighted the world for over three hundred years; the personification of beauty on the outside, but rot within.
Thorgrim Grudgebearer is the current High King of the Dwarfs. He is a throwback to the High Kings of old - eager for new conquests, mighty in battle, and a merciless enemy.

There are few kinds of monsters walking the world that Ungrim Ironfist has not slain in battle. Ungrim deals death - carving a path of red ruin before him while singing songs of old in a booming voice.
Balthasar Gelt is the Supreme Patriarch of the Colleges of Magic. He has only ever been seen swathed in shimmering, metallic robes and wearing a golden mask.

The newly-elected Emperor is Karl Franz, Prince of Altdorf and Elector Count of Reikland. Franz is already garnering a reputation as a great statesman and warrior but has yet to prove himself as sovereign.
Azhag is a threat like no other. What makes Azhag so unusual is his ominous iron crown, which emanates an ancient evil. It is this crown, a relic of olden days, which grants Azhag sorcerous powers.
No one knows much about Grimgor before he staggered out of the Blasted Wastes with the Immortulz, his bloody-minded bodyguard. Even for a Black Orc, Grimgor's thirst for war is exceptional.
Heinrich Kemmler burns with the need for power. Having recognised the limits that mortality placed upon him in his early years, Kemmler made it his life's work to escape them.
Mannfred is no slave to conventions of honour or glory. Ends concern him far more than means; if the choice falls between slaughtering the meek and vanquishing the mighty, he chooses slaughter.
